    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# Only keep relevant columns from the IMDb dataset to avoid duplication.
imdb_df = imdb_df[['title', 'original_air_date', 'imdb_rating', 'total_votes', 'desc']]

brooklyn_99_df = episodes_df.merge(imdb_df, how='left', on=['title', 'original_air_date'])

brooklyn_99_df.head()
source.ce0841cf:
sns.lmplot(x="episode_num_overall", y="imdb_rating", hue="season", data=brooklyn_99_df, height=6, aspect=2, ci=None)
plt.xlabel("Episode")
plt.ylabel("IMDb Rating")
plt.title("IMDb Ratings for Brooklyn 99 episodes")
source.a369fddb: The series stayed fairly consistent throught its first five seasons on FOX, but had a wider spread of ratings after it moved to NBC for seasons 6-8. The last season in particular had a poor start, but the season (and series) finished strong.

source.4d93453c:
### Load and Merge the episode data and IMDb ratings files
A short example notebook to show how to load and merge the data from the two files in the Brooklyn 99 dataset. The common columns are Title and Air Date.
